Fig. 1 Reaction network for hydrogenation (HYD) of 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Reactor schematic for hydrogenation studies. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Apparent activation energy and initial turnover frequencies of IWI Ni catalysts. Turnover frequency reaction conditions: 523 K, 6.9 MPa, 0.15 g catalyst, H2:2-MN molar ratio of 20:1, varied WHSV, < 15% conversion. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TGA curve of oven-dried 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 X-ray diffractograms of the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst and both fresh and spent 60Ni catalyst. Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, University of Maine Orono ME 04469 United States Nickel catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation and coprecipitation and compared to a commercial Ni/kieselguhr catalyst for selective hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to yield methyldecalin. The catalysts were characterized using N2 physisorption, TGA, XRD, and TEM. The apparent activation energy for hydrogenation depends on the support identity, with the highest value (87 kJ/mol) obtained for Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 and the lowest (30 kJ/mol) for Ni/kieselguhr. The selectivity to cis-/trans-methyldecalin varied as a function of both catalyst identity and reaction conditions, with high selectivity to cis-methyldecalin obtained using catalysts with higher Ni loadings and at lower reaction temperatures. The impregnation of a precious metal onto coprecipitated Ni catalysts also changed their selectivity, as catalysts containing ruthenium selectively formed cis-methyldecalin, whereas platinum catalysts produced mostly trans-methyldecalin. This research demonstrates that Ni catalysts can be useful for producing inexpensive catalysts for hydrogenation of polyaromatic-containing feedstocks. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Aromatic hydrogenation Nickel catalysts Bifunctional catalysts Coprecipitated catalysts cis/trans selectivity 1 Introduction Biomass conversion processes, such as pyrolysis, produce mixtures of mono- and poly-aromatic species. Similarly, Thermal DeOxygenation (TDO) can be used to convert organic acids from cellulose hydrolyzate into a low-oxygen bio-oil containing large amounts of substituted naphthalene compounds [1–4]. While such high aromatic content is desirable for use in gasoline, the same is not true for middle-distillate fuels (e.g., jet fuel and diesel), which require upgrading via hydrogenation and ring opening to achieve better combustion characteristics [5,6]. Poly-aromatic molecules, such as the naphthalene derivatives found in TDO oil, are characterized by low cetane numbers. Even deep hydrogenation of such species is often not enough to meet specifications on specific volume, hydrogen content, and cetane number [5,7]. Consequently, one approach for catalytic upgrading of TDO oil is to include not only complete hydrogenation but also naphthenic ring opening while minimizing undesired cracking reactions (which reduce the liquid volume and cetane number of the products) [8–10]. As a first step towards rational design of an upgrading catalyst, we focus in this work on synthesizing efficient methylnaphthalene hydrogenation catalysts. Catalytic hydrogenation is typically performed using either precious metal or sulfided catalysts. Although precious metals, such as Pd and Pt, have higher activities at lower temperatures, they are more sensitive to impurities and are scarce resources [11–15]. Sulfided catalysts, typically based on NiMo or NiW, are disadvantaged because they typically require severe operating conditions and feedstocks that contain sulfur [16–19]. Nickel oxide catalysts, however, are active at moderate conditions and are more readily available than Pd and Pt [5]. There has been limited research on supported nickel catalysts for the hydrogenation of polyaromatic molecules, so in this study we focused on the development of high surface area nickel catalysts for the hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN). Fig. 1 shows the reaction network for hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to yield both partially hydrogenated methyltetralins (MT) and fully hydrogenated methyldecalins (MD). Importantly, there are three stereocenters in MD: two along the fused carbon-carbon bond as well as one at the methyl group position, but in this study, molecules are designated as cis- or trans-MD depending only on the fused stereocenter. The hydrogenation of 2-MN occurs in a sequence of reactions, the first of which is hydrogenation of one ring to produce 2-MT or 6-MT. A second reaction hydrogenates MT to a MD isomer [15,16], which proceeds through a methyloctalin intermediate and has been observed in some studies as a low-concentration product [20–22]. Other studies have shown that for naphthalene hydrogenation, the reaction rate of the hydrogenation of naphthalene to tetralin is at least an order of magnitude faster than the rate of tetralin to decalin [23–25]. Despite this, both Sapre and Gates as well as Huang and Kang both found that these reactions are first order [26,27]. The cis- and trans- stereoisomers of decalin have different chemical properties. First, cis-decalin has a cetane number of 42, whereas the trans- form has a cetane number of 32 [28]. Cis-decalin also has a higher heat of combustion (38.3 versus 37.2 MJ/m3) [20,29]. But perhaps most importantly, cis-decalin is much more likely to be ring-opened over precious metals than trans-decalin [8,30]. While cis-decalin preferentially undergoes ring opening reactions, trans-decalin tends to undergo cracking, producing lower molecular weight fragments that decrease the liquid volume and cetane number of the fuel [8]. Thus, when producing diesel fuels, the desired product is cis-decalin, whereas trans-decalin is desired for jet fuels because it is more thermally stable and inhibits deposition of solid particles [31,32]. Rautanen, et al. performed thermodynamic Gibb’s free energy calculations using a FLOWBAT program and found that at typical reaction temperatures, equilibrium mixtures of decalin contain more than 90% of the trans- isomer [21]. Because it was common to observe more than 10% cis-decalin during hydrogenation, these authors concluded that the cis/trans ratio is governed solely by kinetics and was not limited by thermodynamics. Supporting this hypothesis, Schmitz, et al. showed that the cis/trans ratio is highly dependent on the identity of the metal and support used for hydrogenation [12]. The goal of this research is first to determine the activation energy of 2-MN over various supported Ni catalysts. This work also looks at the mechanism for 2-MN hydrogenation, with a specific focus on the stereochemistry of the resulting methyldecalin isomers. The final goal of this project is to produce monometallic Ni and bimetallic (XNi) catalysts to design a suitable catalyst that selectively produces cis-MD for diesel applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The monometallic Ni catalysts used in this study were produced by either incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) or coprecipitation, while bimetallic catalysts were produced using a combined approach. For the catalysts synthesized by IWI, the supports chosen were SiO2 (Alfa Aesar, silica gel) and γ-Al2O3 (Strem Chemicals). An amorphous silica-alumina (SiO2-Al2O3, ASA) support was also synthesized via sol-gel precipitation using Na4SiO4 (Alfa Aesar, 98%) and AlCl3·6H2O (Alfa Aesar, 99%) in a process similar to another study [33]. In short, one solution of 6 wt% silica was mixed with another solution that contained 6 wt% alumina and enough H2SO4 (Fisher, ACS Plus) to reduce the pH to 0.5. That combined solution was mixed with an 8 wt% NH3 (Merck, 32 wt%) solution, which was stirred vigorously at a neutral pH (6.5 – 7.5) for several hours. The gel was vacuum filtered, washed with 5 wt% ammonium acetate (Fisher, ACS) and then deionized water, and dried overnight in an oven. All IWI catalysts were impregnated using an appropriate amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Alfa Aesar, 98%) and deionized water to reach a metal loading of 20 wt% Ni. Coprecipitated catalysts were prepared by dissolving Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and AlCl3·6H2O in 75 mL of deionized water. Another solution containing 10% excess Na2CO3 (Fisher, 99%) in 50 mL of deionized water was also prepared. Both solutions were added dropwise to a third beaker, which contained 100 mL of deionized water that was vigorously stirred at 363 K. After the solutions were combined, the mixture was filtered with a Büchner funnel to recover the solid particles. The filtrate was then washed with two 100 mL aliquots of deionized water and then with two 25 mL aliquots of methanol. Bimetallic catalysts containing precious metals were synthesized in two steps. First, the coprecipitation method was used to produce a catalyst containing 60 wt% Ni/Al2O3. After the catalyst was dried and calcined, 1 wt% of a second metal was impregnated onto the catalyst via IWI. Palladium (II) chloride (Acros, 99%), chloroplatinic (IV) acid (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%), iridium (IV) chloride (Alfa Aesar, 99.95%), and ruthenium (III) chloride (Alfa Aesar, 99%) were all used as precious metal precursors. After all catalysts were synthesized, they were dried overnight in an oven at 373 K. The resulting catalyst was crushed, sieved to size (150–450 µm), and calcined in air at 723 K for 4 h using a ramp of 2 K/min. Catalysts were reduced in situ under flowing hydrogen (Matheson, Grade 5) at 673 K for 4 h using a heating ramp of 2 K/min. Catalysts synthesized in this study were compared to a commercially available Ni/kieselguhr catalyst, purchased from Alfa Aesar (Catalog No. 31276). Product data sheets from Alfa Aesar indicate this catalyst contains 66 ± 5 wt% Ni. Used catalysts were regenerated by drying the catalyst in an oven at 373 K overnight and subsequently calcining the catalyst in air at 723 K using the same conditions as the other catalyst calcinations. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 N2 physisorption Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 at 77 K. The specific surface areas were calculated using the BET equation, and pore volumes and pore diameters were calculated for the calcined catalysts using the adsorption branch of the BJH equation in combination with the KJS correction. Prior to analysis, samples were degassed at 363 K for 60 min followed by heating the samples to 623 K for 4 h using a heating ramp of 10 K/min. 2.2.2 H2 chemisorption Hydrogen chemisorption was also measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The calcined samples were evacuated at room temperature then reduced under flowing hydrogen at 673 K for 4 h at a rate of 2 K/min. The sample was then evacuated again and cooled to the analysis temperature of 308 K. A repeat analysis was also used to distinguish between the hydrogen uptake from the metal compared with the uptake by the support. ﻿Adsorption stoichiometry of n H / n Ni = 1 was assumed as well as a hemispherical nanoparticle shape. The metal particle diameter ( d m ) was estimated by: (1) d m = 1.1 D where D is the catalyst dispersion, which was calculated as the number of surface Ni atoms divided by the total number of Ni atoms [34]. 2.2.3 Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TA Instruments Q500. TGA was used to determine the temperature required for calcination. Pre-calcined catalysts were dried in an oven overnight at 373 K prior to testing. The sample temperatures were ramped at 10 K/min from room temperature to 1050 K under flowing air (50 mL/min) and nitrogen (50 mL/min). 2.2.4 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a Panalytical X-Pert Pro using a Cu Kα X-ray source. Calcined catalyst samples suspended on a glass plate mounted on the goniometer. X-rays were delivered through a parabolic mirror, 10 mm mask, and slit of 0.5°. Diffractograms were collected over a 2θ range from 20° to 80° using a 255-channel PIXCEL solid state detector. 2.2.5 Transmission electron microscopy Electron micrographs were obtained using a Philips CM10 transmission electron microscope (TEM) with an electron gun operating at 100 kV. Catalyst samples were dispersed onto a coated copper grid and micrographs were obtained using a built-in Orius SC200 CCD Camera. 2.3 Reactivity measurements Catalytic reactions were carried out in a high-pressure, stainless steel trickle-bed reactor system illustrated in Fig. 2. Calcined catalyst was mixed with carborundum (Pfaltz & Bauer, 99%) to aid in heat transfer and was packed between plugs of quartz wool to aid in liquid distribution and reduce void volume in the reactor. Reactions were carried out at temperatures between 473 and 623 K at 6.9 MPa total pressure with weight hourly space velocities (WHSV) ranging from 0.1 to 1.0 h−1 and H2/2-MN ratios of 20:1 or 40:1 (mol:mol). The liquid feed to the reactor consisted of 10 wt% 2-MN in n-decane solvent (Alfa Aesar, 99%). A sulfur impurity (5-methylbenzo[b]thiophene) was present at about 25 ppm in the commercial 2-MN (Alfa Aesar, 97%) used in this experiment. Thus, the 2-MN was first purified by recrystallization in n-decane, thereby decreasing the sulfur concentration below 5 ppm. All liquid samples were collected and analyzed on a gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) using a Restek Rxi-5 ms column (30 m x 0.25 mmID x 0.25 µm). Biphenyl was used as an internal standard and peaks were identified by comparing to known standards as well as comparing to the NIST database of mass spectra. Reaction products were grouped into five categories: a). ROP – ring opening products, b). MD – methyldecalins, c). MT – methyltetralins, d). MN - methylnaphthalene (2-MN and 1-MN) and e). CP - cracked products (products with less than 11 carbon atoms). A total product analysis containing a GC-MS chromatogram is provided in the Supporting Information. Mass balances typically closed to greater than 98 wt%, suggesting minimal cracking of 2-MN or n-decane to form vapor-phase species. Additionally, there was very limited isomerization of 2-MN to 1-methylnaphthalene (1-MN). Conversion of 2-MN was defined as: (2) X = n ̇ 2 MN , in − n ̇ 2 MN , out n ̇ 2 MN , in where X is the conversion, n ̇ 2 MN , in is the molar flow rate of 2-MN flowing into the reactor, and n ̇ 2 MN , out is the molar flow rate of 2-MN collected as products. The conversion was calculated by converting the GC-MS peak areas into molar concentrations using a calibration curve and then determining the difference in the 2-MN concentration. For all of the experiments, the conversion was increased or decreased by varying only the WHSV. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by dividing the initial reaction rate by the site density and was measured at low conversions (less than 15%). The product selectivity ( S i ) and cis-MD selectivity ( S cis ) were defined as: (3) S i = n ̇ i n ̇ products (4) S cis = n ˙ MD , cis n ˙ MD where n ̇ i is the molar flow rate of species i , n ̇ products is the product molar flow rate, n ̇ MD , cis is the molar flow rate of cis-MD and n ̇ MD is the molar flow rate of all MD isomers. Although there are three points of stereochemistry in MD, we ignored the stereochemistry of the methyl group because combustion characteristics are much more dependent on the shape of the saturated ring than the axial or equatorial position of the methyl group [20]. Reproducibility was verified by performing multiple experiments at the same temperature to determine the activation energy barriers. The standard error was calculated for each initial reaction rate (which we used to correct for catalyst deactivation), as well as the error in calculating the rate constants in the Arrhenius equation. Multiple hydrogenation trials were conducted to determine the error in the cis-MD selectivity for each catalyst at 623 K, and the error bars represent the 95% confidence interval. To determine the presence of mass transport limitations, the Madon-Boudart Criterion [35] was applied to the coprecipitated catalysts, and a description of the criterion and calculations are in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activation energy and turnover frequency of IWI catalysts Activation energy studies focused on determining the activation energy of 2-MN hydrogenation using Ni catalysts supported on several oxides via incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). Table 1 shows physisorption and chemisorption measurements of those catalysts. In collecting data, the rates were obtained at differential conversion (less than 15%). Because the catalysts rapidly deactivated over the course of the reaction (likely due to methyltetralin dissociation and inhibition on the catalyst surface [36,37]), initial rates were obtained by extrapolating to zero time and were used as metrics for catalyst performance. Activation energies were obtained from pseudo-first-order rate constants using the linearized Arrhenius equation, and can be found in Fig. 3, as well as catalyst turnover frequencies (TOF). The activation energy obtained using the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst was lowest (30 kJ/mol), while that obtained using Ni supported on amorphous silica-alumina (Ni/ASA) was the highest (87 kJ/mol). The activation energies obtained using Ni/SiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 were between these two extremes. Generally speaking, acid site strength increases according to SiO2 < Al2O3 < ASA [38], which matches the trend in activation energies shown in Fig. 3. However, for Brønsted catalyzed reactions, increases in acid strength generally lead to lower activation energy barriers [39]. With that in mind, the observed differences in activation energy are not likely due to the difference in acid site strength. The Ni particle size of the incipient wetness catalysts is displayed in Table 1, and with the exception of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/Al2O3, the activation energy increases as the particle size increases. The activation energy difference could also be due to this trend, but at large nanoparticle sizes, we are aware that the metal would begin to resemble bulk Ni [40]. Also shown in Fig. 3 are initial turnover frequencies for the IWI catalysts. Both the Ni/SiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts have low TOF of 2.9 and 2.4 ks−1 respectively. The Ni/ASA catalyst has a higher value at 4.9 ks−1, but they are all much lower than the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst, which has a TOF of 10.4 ks−1. 3.2 Conversion and selectivity of coprecipitated catalysts Because the IWI catalysts had low turnover frequencies and deactivated rapidly, we synthesized several different catalysts to find ones with higher reaction rates and turnover frequencies. In another study, it was found that the nickel precursor played a role in the Ni/Al2O3 deactivation as well as the final decalin stereochemistry [41]. They found that after 30 h on stream with tetralin feed, catalysts prepared with nickel carbonate lost about 10% conversion, while the nickel nitrate catalyst lost more than twice that. They also showed that at 64% tetralin conversion, the former catalysts produced about 55% selectivity towards cis-decalin, while the latter was only about 36% selective to cis-decalin, indicating that the precursor plays a role in the decalin stereoselectivity. We produced a coprecipitated Ni catalyst containing nickel carbonate as the metal precursor. That catalyst also had the same metal loading as the Ni/Al2O3 IWI catalyst aforementioned in Table 1. We discovered that coprecipitated catalysts had higher turnover frequencies and cis-MD selectivities when compared to their IWI counterparts. The 20 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by IWI had a TOF of 2.4 ks−1, while the TOF of the coprecipitated 20 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was three times larger at 7.6 ks−1 (see Table 2). The cis-MD selectivity, as defined in Eq. 4, is different for each of the two catalysts studied here. When both catalysts were used to hydrogenate a feed to 60% conversion using the reaction conditions described in Table 2, it was found that the IWI catalyst exhibited a cis-MD selectivity of 29%, while the coprecipitated catalyst exhibited a selectivity of 52%. For these reasons, coprecipitated Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with Ni loadings between 20 and 80 wt% were further studied. To avoid unnecessarily high temperatures that would cause catalyst sintering, TGA was used to determine the temperature required to decompose the nickel carbonate catalyst precursor. A representative thermogram for an oven-dried (prior to calcination) 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 4. The most significant mass loss occurs at 550 K, and there is only minimal mass loss above 650 K. For this reason, we chose 723 K for catalyst calcination. Ma, et al. [42] showed that bulk NiO catalysts (such as the coprecipitated catalysts synthesized in this study) reduce fully at 640 K, but other studies have shown higher reduction temperatures for supported Ni catalysts if there was formation of NiAl2O4 spinel [31,43,44]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) verified the absence of nickel aluminate in the coprecipitated catalysts, and the results are displayed in Fig. 5. Fig. 5 shows X-ray diffractograms for the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst, as well as the fresh 60Ni/Al2O3 and a spent 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst that has undergone regeneration. Three reflections are visible for the coprecipitated 60Ni/Al2O3 catalysts at 37.5°, 43.3°, and 62.7°. These reflections do not correspond to nickel aluminate spinel, but instead correspond to the peaks for NiO, which appear at 37.3°, 43.3°, and 62.9° and represent (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes respectively [45,46]. These reflections also had similar relative intensities to those reported by Richardson, et al., who also observed reflections for NiO (3 1 1) and (2 2 2) planes at 75.4° and 79.4°, respectively [45]. The relative intensities of these reflections were much lower than the other planes, suggesting they are probably near the sensitivity limit of the instrument used here. Given the X-ray diffractograms, there was a low probability that spinel-like structures exist in the coprecipitated catalysts. The diffractograms for the fresh and spent 60Ni/Al2O3 catalysts display similar reflections, but these appear to be more defined in the spent sample, indicating larger crystallite sizes, as per the Scherrer equation. This observation is realistic because some sintering probably occurred during the reaction, which would increase the particle size. The Ni/kieselguhr catalyst shows a small reflection at 43.3°, but none of the other reflections for NiO. It also displays a sharp reflection at 26.4°, which we speculate is due to an α-SiO2 (0 1 1) plane [47] because the catalyst contains kieselguhr (which contains amorphous silica and other compounds). The series of monometallic Ni coprecipitated catalysts is shown in Table 3 along with physisorption, chemisorption, and turnover frequency data. The N2 physisorption measurements in Table 3 show that the surface area and pore volume decreased as the catalyst Ni content increased. The lower percentage Ni catalysts (i.e., 20, 40, 60% Ni) appear to decrease in a somewhat linear fashion, but there was a large drop in surface area and pore volume for the 80Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The metal nanoparticle size was fairly consistent for the synthesized catalysts, and it was found that the 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst had the smallest particle size, but not by much. Turnover frequencies were also calculated for each of the coprecipitated catalysts, and it was found that the 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst also has the highest turnover frequency, which is very close to the TOF calculated for the commercial Ni/kieselguhr catalyst (9.3 vs. 10.4 ks−1). There also is a decrease in TOF at high Ni content, and a plot of turnover frequency as a function of metal nanoparticle diameter is approximately linear. Table 3 presents the characteristics of a fresh 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst along with one that was reacted then regenerated. The surface area decreased after reaction while the pore volume and pore size were not significantly altered. However, the metal particle size increased after reaction, in agreement with the XRD diffractogram in Fig. 5, which shows that the spent catalyst had sharper peaks and thus larger crystallite sizes. In addition to the higher turnover frequencies, the coprecipitated catalysts had higher cis-MD selectivities than the IWI catalysts. Although we were primarily interested in the selectivity towards cis-MD, there were other products formed in the reaction (though a vast majority of them were methyltetralins). A total product analysis is shown in the Supporting Information along with a chromatogram displaying the compounds present. A plot showing the cis-MD selectivity as a function of reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 6, but for each reaction, the WHSV was varied to maintain around 60% conversion. Fig. 6 shows the cis-MD selectivity of the coprecipitated catalysts. The plot shows that the amount of cis-MD produced is slightly dependent on the amount of Ni in the catalyst, but the reaction temperature appears to be more important. This is consistent with results of Huang and Kang as well as Rautanen, et al., who both showed that the cis/trans ratio was dependent on the catalyst activity and slightly dependent on the reaction temperature [21,48]. Our results also show that the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst has a similar cis-MD selectivity (at about 60% 2-MN conversion) as most of the coprecipitated catalysts. Given the similar selectivities, turnover frequencies, and Ni content between the 60Ni/Al2O3 (60 wt% Ni) and Ni/kieselguhr catalyst (66 ± 5 wt% Ni), we analyzed samples on a TEM to look at their nanostructures, which are displayed in Fig. 7. Fig. 7 shows TEM images of the 60Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/kieselguhr commercial catalyst. The 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst shows rod-like structures, while nodule-like structures coat the surface of the Ni/kieselguhr catalyst. These nanostructures probably account for the difference in the BET surface area, pore volume, and metal nanoparticle size of the catalysts (as shown in Table 3). Despite their differences, the cis-MD selectivity of the catalysts was similar. It is possible that the hydrogenation is not structure-specific, or it could be that the differences in nanostructures (and thus ensemble and site coordination) were not sufficient to dramatically alter the selectivity. 3.3 Methyldecalin selectivity of bimetallic coprecipitated catalysts While most aromatic hydrogenation studies focus on the use of monometallic catalysts, some bimetallic catalysts have been shown to enhance reaction rates or selectively produce isomers. Of these, bimetallic catalysts of platinum and palladium have been widely studied over a variety of supports for aromatic hydrogenation [11,24,49,50], but there is limited information on bimetallic nickel hydrogenation catalysts. Using incipient wetness impregnation, we incorporated 1 wt% of several precious metals onto a 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The cis-MD selectivities of these catalysts are shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8 shows that the incorporation of a second metal onto the catalyst surface dramatically changed the cis-MD selectivity for some metals. The catalyst containing small amounts of platinum (PtNi/Al2O3) produced more trans-MD, but the catalyst containing ruthenium (RuNi/Al2O3) increased the formation of cis-MD. The catalysts containing palladium (PdNi/Al2O3) and iridium (IrNi/Al2O3) had somewhat similar selectivities to the monometallic 60Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. There are several possible explanations for the dramatic change in selectivity shown Fig. 8. One possible explanation was a difference in the methyloctalin intermediate formed, while another possibility was that the addition of a second metal creates or destroys some metal ensembles that hydrogenate to certain isomers. To our knowledge, there have not been any studies of bimetallic Ni catalysts that looked at the stereochemistry of the decalin (or methyldecalin) species formed. However, there have been other studies using monometallic Pt that showed a tendency to produce trans- stereoisomers. Huang and Kang studied naphthalene hydrogenation and Jaroszewska, et al., studied 1-methylnaphthalene hydrogenation over Pt catalysts, and each showed that trans- isomers were selectively produced [48,51]. There is very limited research on hydrogenation of aromatics with Ru-based catalysts, but Weitkamp studied naphthalene hydrogenation using Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/C catalysts [20]. It was found that all Ru catalysts were highly selective for the formation of cis-decalin and for some catalysts, the cis- selectivity was in excess of 95% at conversions ranging from 5% to 90%. In that same review, Weitkamp proposed a series of steps for the hydrogenation of tetralin to the cis- and trans- forms of decalin, which is shown in Fig. 9 [20]. Ignoring the presence of hexalin (hexahydronaphthalene), which likely only exists as an adsorbed reactive intermediate, tetralin is hydrogenated through an octalin intermediate to produce either cis- or trans-decalin. The Δ9,10-octalin intermediate is more thermodynamically favorable, and only reacts to form cis-decalin or irreversibly isomerizes to Δ1,9-octalin [21]. This is in contrast to Δ1,9-octalin, which can be hydrogenated to both isomers of decalin. However, when comparing the reaction rates, Smith and Burwell showed that the rate of Δ1,9-octalin hydrogenation was 25 times more than Δ9,10-octalin on Pt [52]. Weitkamp also went one step further and showed that Ru catalysts on multiple supports all produced large quantities of Δ9,10-octalin, much higher than Ir, Pd, and Pt catalysts on similar supports [20]. In the present study, we found that at low temperatures, the RuNi/Al2O3 catalyst produced Δ9,10-methyloctalin almost 20-fold more than Δ1,9-methyloctalin. However, the PtNi/Al2O3 catalyst produced minimal quantities of methyloctalin intermediate (of any isomer) and the ratio between the stereoisomers was almost unity. Because Δ9,10-methyloctalin can only be hydrogenated to the cis- isomer, we believe that the high concentration of this intermediate is the reason why the RuNi/Al2O3 catalyst selectively produced cis-MD. Conversely, in the hydrogenation studies mentioned beforehand, there was an abundance of trans- products formed on monometallic Pt catalysts. Additionally, the high Δ1,9-octalin hydrogenation rate that Smith and Burwell showed as well as the relative absence of Δ9,10-methyloctalin in this study could explain why PtNi/Al2O3 preferentially produces trans-MD. However, another possible explanation for the observed shift in selectivities could be the formation or destruction of metal ensembles. During incipient wetness impregnation, the second metal particles were dispersed on the catalyst surface, both as standalone metal sites and as bimetallic nanoparticles [10]. Because these hydrogenation reactions are somewhat structure-sensitive [53,54], there might be changes in the product selectivity as the surface structure is altered. Puddu and Ponec observed that adding small quantities of gold to a platinum catalyst shut off benzene hydrogenation [55]. The authors suggested that this was due to a geometric effect, specifically that the addition of gold was destroying large ensembles of platinum required for the hydrogenation of benzene. That could be a similar situation to what is occurring here, as the addition of Pt to Ni destroys the active sites needed to produce cis-MD, or vice versa with the RuNi/Al2O3 catalyst and trans-MD. 4 Conclusions Various supported nickel catalysts were synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation, coprecipitation, and a combination of both methods. Using pseudo-first-order rate constants from a linearized Arrhenius equation, we determined the activation energy and turnover frequencies of several impregnated catalysts. The Ni/kieselguhr catalyst displayed the lowest activation energy, while the Ni/ASA catalyst displayed the highest activation energy. Coprecipitated Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were found to have higher turnover frequencies and increased cis-MD selectivities compared to incipient wetness impregnation catalysts. TEM images of 60Ni/Al2O3 coprecipitated catalysts showed rod-like structures, while the commercial Ni/kieselguhr catalyst showed nodule-like structures although they both displayed similar cis-MD selectivity. The cis-MD selectivity was also found to be dependent on the reaction temperature and slightly dependent on the amount of Ni in the catalyst. Although impregnation of Pd and Ir onto 60Ni/Al2O3 did not noticeably change the cis-MD selectivity, the addition of Pt and Ru had a marked difference, with the former producing trans- isomers and the latter producing cis- isomers. We hypothesized that this difference in reactivity was either caused by preferential formation of different methyloctalin intermediates or by the creation/destruction of active site ensembles on the catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: Nickel catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation and coprecipitation and compared to a commercial Ni/kieselguhr catalyst for selective hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to yield methyldecalin. The catalysts were characterized using N2 physisorption, TGA, XRD, and TEM. The apparent activation energy for hydrogenation depends on the support identity, with the highest value (87 kJ/mol) obtained for Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 and the lowest (30 kJ/mol) for Ni/kieselguhr. The selectivity to cis-/trans-methyldecalin varied as a function of both catalyst identity and reaction conditions, with high selectivity to cis-methyldecalin obtained using catalysts with higher Ni loadings and at lower reaction temperatures. The impregnation of a precious metal onto coprecipitated Ni catalysts also changed their selectivity, as catalysts containing ruthenium selectively formed cis-methyldecalin, whereas platinum catalysts produced mostly trans-methyldecalin. This research demonstrates that Ni catalysts can be useful for producing inexpensive catalysts for hydrogenation of polyaromatic-containing feedstocks.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene over bi-functional Ni catalysts
